body:

(Do I need to regenerate explicitly?
I re-executed [the step](https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/tree/master/protobuf#commands-for-creating-the-pre-generated-java-code) but that made no differences)
retest this please
@lucperkins Maybe we should add some high level info on what kind of operations the tool is useful for.
@cckellogg is the change for consumers coming in a different PR?
/cc @merlimat @zhaijack
/cc @lucperkins
@rdhabalia wouldn't make sense to incorporate into the existing `managed-ledger-admin` tool?
/cc @mgodave @merlimat
This is a question raised up based on looking into the code. We need to verify if we have any tricks on cpp client. /cc @merlimat

Actually this is a replacement of `zookeeper-shell` which is simple to traverse and access znode paths for debugging but it doesn't show human-readable data for managed-ledger so, we need to access `managed-ledger-admin` which requires many different commands to access it.
I think `managed-ledger-admin` could be more useful to write any cleanup/monitoring/ml-update script on top of it.
@merlimat I will! This is just a work in progress.
@merlimat yes a follow up pr for the consumers is coming after this one.
retest this please

change LGTM - one question though - why keep two separate commands/options

Why not point zookeeper-shell to org.apache.zookeeper.ZooKeeperManagedLedgerMain

If the data is not in binary format won't zookeeper-ml-shell print the data as it is
retest this please

> Why not point zookeeper-shell to org.apache.zookeeper.ZooKeeperManagedLedgerMain

 `zookeeper-ml-shell` parses the binary data and prints in text format and if we give as default option then it may confuse users as they may think that broker always writes into text format so, I have added additional command.
+1, Thanks for it @lucperkins

> I realised we only use a single thread executor per Consumer instance, is there a reason for this? 

The main reason is to retain the message ordering. This might not be important in a shared subscription but it is for the other types.

> I think it would be nice to be able to disable externalExecutorProvider in PulsarClientImpl 

Sounds good to me. As long as we document the behavior and the user knows that it has to do non-blocking operations (or else slow down potentially the consumption for other consumers in the same client).

> If implementing the previous, it would probably make more sense to use MoreExecutors.newDirectExecutorService() though we probably shouldn't use a single instance but a few, but it could be hard to track them and shut them down.

I think that `newDirectExecutorService()` should just return a simple lambda that execute directly, there shouldn't be the need to have multiple instances of it, no?

I think it becomes a bit tricky, because if you want to configure some options through env variables, you might as well need to configure them all. 

For example, what happens if the variable is not defined in 

```shell
webServicePort=${webServicePort}
```

I think that falling back to default should be the best option. 

For updating the config file through environment variables, there is already a tool in  [docker/scripts/apply-config-from-env.py](https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/blob/master/docker/scripts/apply-config-from-env.py), that updates the config files replacing the variables that are being overwritten through the enviroment.

> Load-manager should not overload broker with topics higher than max-limit.

I think that coming up with max limit setting in practice might be tricky. In this case are topics offline if the max is reached on a given broker and there are no brokers available?
 
Wouldn't it be a better option to treat it as a "target" limit, that can passed if the need arises, though the topics will be shedded whenever there additional brokers will be available?

> Actually this is a replacement of zookeeper-shell which is simple to traverse and access znode paths 

Well, the `zookeeper-shell` is supposed to mimic the bash shell :) 

The part I don't understand is why do we need a separate tool and how would this be different than doing: 

```
pulsar-managed-ledger-admin print-managed-ledger $MY_MANAGED_LEDGER
```

> Well, the zookeeper-shell is supposed to mimic the bash shell :)

Yes, actually this tool does the same as it's a wrapper on top of `ZooKeeperMain` and it mimics bash shell but it also parses all ml and ml-cursor's data.

> The part I don't understand is why do we need a separate tool and how would this be different than doing: pulsar-managed-ledger-admin print-managed-ledger $MY_MANAGED_LEDGER

Probably same thing but it just mimics bash-shell so, convenient to use.

> I think that falling back to default should be the best option.

Sure.

>For updating the config file through environment variables, there is already a tool in docker/scripts/apply-config-from-env.py,

Yes, but here only difference is that it helps without modifying files. So, it will also help in testing while starting multiple instance using the same file.

> Yes, but here only difference is that it helps without modifying files. So, it will also help in testing while starting multiple instance using the same file.

For this last case, I'd prefer to allow CLI parameter overrides, in that it's more explicit of where the setting is coming from
@cckellogg There's a small conflict to resolve

@jai1 This change is adding or changing the behavior of a big component and adding new metadata options. Can you create a PIP wiki page and start the discussion on the mailing list to review the design doc?

`String.hashCode()` uses the simple hash. On the other side, `boost::hash` uses MurmurHash3. IMO, we have to use widely-used and good hash like MurmurHash in each language client.
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/String.html

The biggest problem is how to upgrade the default hashing scheme. New applications can easily use different hashing, but who's using the current client and relies on hashing cannot just switch to a new scheme.

@Licht-T @merlimat 

I think the easiest way is to create a separate message router that uses MurmurHash3. Ask applications to use this new message router.
@saandrews @merlimat  ping

I had this in the back of my mind but didn't want to push my first PR too
far. I think we can incrementally add this. I'm not on my computer at the
moment, I'll take a closer look in a little.

On Tue, Jan 2, 2018, 15:54 Matteo Merli <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> @mgodave <https://github.com/mgodave> Change looks good. One other option
> I didn't think about it before was to introduce concept of builder for
> producer/consumer/reader. Would it help to make it easier to introduce the
> types as well?
>
> I was thinking something like:
>
> client.newConsumer(myTopic, mySubName).withSchema(mySchema).withListener( (c, msg) -> {
>   // ...
> }).build();
> // or .buildAsync() to get a future
>
> 
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
>
>
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/pull/1008#issuecomment-354897267>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAh9FugQEGpaa5TtuRgglY3kKLFZ16ULks5tGrO-gaJpZM4RLVbV>
> .
>

> I think we can incrementally add this 

+1 to this. I think it makes it nicer by not having many overloaded methods, and also easy to check the types for both the `Schema` and the `Listener` which will be typed as well. 

One thing: if we end up doing the refactoring for 1.22 as well, we can just remove these new methods without going through the deprecation process.
If we need ordering the probably it makes more sense to use `EventLoopGroup` as an executor rather than using DirectExecutors
tested the new command under docker, and worked fine.

@lucperkins I actually found out a way to have the direct download through the mirror redirection. For example : 

```shell
wget -O apache-pulsar-1.21.0-incubating-bin.tar.gz \
'https://www.apache.org/dyn/mirrors/mirrors.cgi?action=download&filename=incubator/pulsar/pulsar-1.21.0-incubating/apache-pulsar-1.21.0-incubating-bin.tar.gz'
```
If it is OK, I would like to contribute on this issue
as discussed, we might consider documenting what special characters can't be used in pulsar service uri.

@merlimat These already exist.
https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-client-cpp/.gitignore#L59
This was fixed in 1.21 release

Could we piggyback the last message for the topic on the messages as they are being sent from the broker to the client. The client could then cache this info and if it sees it as being stale enough, make a request to the broker.

LGTM

> @merlimat Almost fixed. What should I do on the mock test? 

I think we cannot break the binary compatibility at this point. We could do that once we move to Pulsar 2.0 (which should happen soon), but in the meantime we shouldn't be changing the method signatures.

This is GREAT! Just out of curiosity, can we really use any listed version of clang tools? Actually Apache Traffic Server project uses clang-format too, but they stick with a specific version on all supported platforms because outputs from different versions are slightly different.

Thanks @merlimat!
- The deprecated virtual method `int getPartition(const Message&)` is now throws `DeprecatedException`.
- Reverted the change in `Message` class and mock tests is disabled.
Implements #967

> This is GREAT! Just out of curiosity, can we really use any listed version of clang tools? Actually Apache Traffic Server project uses clang-format too, but they stick with a specific version on all supported platforms because outputs from different versions are slightly different.

Good point, I think the reference version would be the one used in the Jenkins build, since it will be used to do the validation and it will reject PRs with unconforming code.

We should point out the version in the docs to make it clear

OK, fixed all the tests, I had an issue locally that made the tests take hours to run locally but we're all set now. My thought is that once this is merged I can modify #987 and remove type information from the Configuration objects and add it to these new methods. I will still deprecate the handlers in the Configuration objects.

>  I guess we can't perform git revert in this state? 

I actually did the git revert

> if the max is reached on a given broker and there are no brokers available?

In that case, load-manager is already [performing broker-selection again](https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/pull/919) without that filter and it selects least loaded broker.

>  though the topics will be shedded whenever there additional brokers will be available?

yes, we can add this variable for load-shedding as well but this helps in very beginning while loading topic at broker which can avoid bundle-unloading after 30 mins. In few usecases, we may want to disable load-shedding  in cluster to avoid in bundle disruption or topic-stuck due to some unloading-bugs. So, it's always good if broker considers max topic limit while selecting broker. 

Actually, main motivation of this change is that broker has certain limit for owning X (eg:60K) number of topics after that broker sees obvious GC as each topic allocates large number of `Rate` and other objects even if topics are idle. we can verify and check in heapdump of broker that owns > 60K topics.
@merlimat @sijie , for the new config, which name do you like, "replication-configuration", "--configuration-zookeeper" or "geo-configuration-zookeeper" "global-configuration-zookeeper"

Actually global-zookeeper is not only used to store replication/geo metadata but it also stores various namespace and admin policies. So, I think we should not rename it to something specific for replication.
Isn't `global-zookeeper` is acceptable name as it's being shared by different clusters?
As @sijie mentioned, there may be some mis-leading for new user.

@rdhabalia we learned from our customers that 'global-zookeeper' is a bit confusing. people feels that the global zookeeper is the single point of failure, when it is down, pulsar is not functionable. since it is mostly used for configuration/policies, it is better to rename it to make the meaning more clear, so people will know directly that it is used for storing configurations/policies and they will not be freak out, or having other bad impressions.

I was thinking of `configuration-zookeeper`, because policies are sort of "configuration"s.
The zipped data directory can be found here: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1jo7O41mQ9Elcs581jzYiS9dNla4csdab/view?usp=sharing
A rocksdb issue was reported at facebook/rocksdb#2717

Updated the build image. 

retest this please
I would suggest `configuration-store`, then we can think how to present that it's actually implemented with zookeeper.
Thanks @merlimat,  will wait for 1 day, and if there is no objection, will do the change, and send a new PR.

Thanks @merlimat,  will wait for 1 day, and if there is no objection for name `configuration-store`, will do the change in the code, and send a new PR.
@sijie @rdhabalia for the new name `configuration-store`.
Will add one

> Good point, I think the reference version would be the one used in the Jenkins build, since it will be used to do the validation and it will reject PRs with unconforming code.

Right, and we need to choose the version carefully. Because packaged clang-format is sometimes too old (or new), you would need to build it by yourself in that case and too newer versions might bring some build issue on older platforms.

> We should point out the version in the docs to make it clear

It'll be a good start. However, requiring building clang-format would set a high bar for making a PR, especially to new contributors. I think we should probably make the clang-format check on PRs optional so that we can merge PRs regardless of the results and run clang-format later. 

Just for your information, ATS project provide a couple of clang-format binaries for macOS and Linux, and `make clang-format` fetches one of the binaries automatically so that contributors can make PRs easily.
https://github.com/apache/trafficserver/blob/master/tools/clang-format.sh

Anyway, I'm really glad to see this PR. We should discuss details (e.g. coding styles, merging rules) on dev@.
Thanks @merlimat, now all green!

@maskit @merlimat I think `clang-format-4.0` is the best because it is easy to install by package systems in any OS.

Also, we can specify the `clang-format` version as the CMake setting.
https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/pull/1038/files#diff-bda8db832e446d092d38464123ed17bcR201

Here is the build document.
https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/pull/1038/files#diff-fe0ebbf484d5c36dafeff28e5001b06aR173
If we need additional documentation, I'll do that.

@Licht-T 

> I think clang-format-4.0 is the best because it is easy to install by package systems in any OS.

IMO, that wouldn't be a enough reason. Probably, at least one version is available on any popular OS's packaging systems, but I'm not sure whether the version is 4.0. If I simply install clang-format package with Homebrew, the version is 6.0. I think it would be 3.x if it was CentOS6, which is not EOLed yet. And Fedora 28 will be released with 5.0 in 6 months.

Another issue on packaging systems is that even if several major versions are available on a packaging system, you can't install two versions of the same package without a trick, as far as I know. This means that contributors may need to downgrade the package prior to making a PR. This is the reason that you would need to build it by yourself. (Now I found pre-built binaries are available on official download page.)
@Licht-T @maskit I think the easiest way is to point the devs to use the `clang-format` from the pulsar-build Docker image.
I am making some changes (eg. #1029) on C++ client and I want to make codes formatted before these approved. Would you mind if I do `clang-format` on this PR?
